title: 2D motion - heights at different launch speeds

content.question: Object <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is launched at an initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> at an angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> above the horizontal and reaches a maximum height of <math alttext="y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Object <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is launched at an initial speed <math alttext="2 times v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> at the same angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>, reaching a maximum height of <math alttext="y sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. What is the relationship between <math alttext="y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="y sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="y sub 2, equals y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="y sub 2 equals the square root of 2, end root, times y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="y sub 2 equals 2 y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="y sub 2 equals 4 y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="y sub 2 equals 4 y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

topic.text: 1.5: Motion in Two or Three Dimensions

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
